entry.title: Greek PM Tsipras rallies Syriza backing before bailout vote
entry.summary: The heads of the centrist To Potami party and the socialist Pasok party both said they would back the Tsipras government over the bailout accord but demanded a clear "road map" from the prime minister about what would happen after that.

entry.title: Greece's Tsipras Stays Popular Despite Bailout Hardship
Greece's Tsipras stays popular despite bailout hardship
entry.summary:
Under Alexis Tsipras, Greece slid back into recession, sank deeper into debt and saw unemployment spike.

Under Alexis Tsipras, Greece slid back into recession, sank deeper into debt and found itself pushed to the brink of bankruptcy.

entry.title: Greek banks reopen as Tsipras eyes return to normal
Greek banks reopen as government eyes return to normalcy
entry.summary: But Tsipras is eyeing a fresh start and swift talks on the bailout that will keep Greece afloat.

entry.title: Greek banks to re-open Monday as Tsipras eyes new start
entry.summary: Acceptance of the tough bailout terms marked a turnaround for Tsipras after months of acrimonious talks and a referendum that resoundingly rejected a less stringent deal proposed by the lenders.

entry.title: Greek banks to re-open Monday as Tsipras eyes new start
entry.summary:
The Greek government ordered banks to open on Monday, three weeks after they were shut down to prevent the system collapsing under a flood of withdrawals, as Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras looked to the start of new bailout talks next week.

The decree to re-open the banks came hours after new ministers were sworn in following a cabinet reshuffle in which Tsipras replaced dissident members of his ruling Syriza party following a revolt over the tough bailout terms.

The reshuffle allowed Tsipras to replace cabinet rebels with allies of his own or from his junior coalition partners, the right-wing Independent Greeks party.

Tsipras now intends to seal the bailout accord with European partners over the next few weeks before likely new elections which Interior Minister Nikos Voutsis said this week could happen in September or October.

entry.title: German lawmakers back Greek bailout, Tsipras sacks dissenters
Greece's Tsipras reshuffles Cabinet after austerity vote prompted dissent in his party
On the brink, EU leaders clinched bailout deal _ with an SMS
entry.summary:
Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras speaks with the media after a meeting of eurozone heads of state at the EU Council building in Brussels on Monday, July 13, 2015.

The overwhelming "No" vote in the July 5 referendum was a triumph for Tsipras.

At first Tsipras wanted 25 billion euros of the package to be available for investments, while Merkel insisted on only 10 billion euros for that purpose.

entry.title: On the brink, EU leaders clinched bailout deal _ with an SMS
entry.summary:
For three hours, Merkel, Tsipras, Tusk and French President Francois Hollande had been stuck in dead-end closed-door talks, and the message suddenly made something click.

Tsipras returned to the Greek capital that night, and hastily convened his Cabinet.

entry.title: Reluctant Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras fights to pass reforms in Greek parliament
entry.summary: Anti-Euro protesters march through the streets during an anti-austerity rally in Athens, as Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras battled to win lawmakers' approval on Wednesday for a bailout deal.

entry.title: Reluctant Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras fights to pass reforms in Greek parliament
entry.summary:
The ruling Syriza party, elected in January on an anti-austerity platform, has been deeply split by the bailout deal that a reluctant Tsipras was forced to accept after gruelling negotiations in Brussels this week.

But around 30-40 Syriza lawmakers are likely either to abstain or vote against the government, raising a question mark over how long Tsipras can remain in office.

Former finance minister Yanis Varoufakis, who was sacked by Tsipras last week, denounced the bailout as "a new Versailles Treaty" - the agreement that demanded unaffordable reparations from Germany after World War One.

entry.title: Reluctant Tsipras fights to pass reforms in Greek parliament
entry.summary: Tsipras is expected to reshuffle his cabinet after the vote, replacing Lafazanis and Deputy Labour Minister Dimitris Stratoulis, another bailout opponent, and possibly making other changes as well.

entry.title: Reluctant Tsipras fights to pass reforms in Greek parliament
entry.summary: Tsipras will put the bailout package to parliament while grappling with noisy opposition from within his own ranks.

entry.title: Reluctant Tsipras fights to pass reforms in Greek parliament
entry.summary:
Tsipras has described the deal as a "one-way street" imposed on Greece and the rest of his government shared his scepticism.

Pointing to Washington's importance in the talks, Deputy Prime Minister Yannis Dragasakis said the deal Tsipras struck with creditors might never have happened without U.S. pressure.

Syriza's junior coalition partner said it would vote only for certain clauses in the bill, rejecting those reforms that went beyond a previous vote in parliament that had given Tsipras a mandate to negotiate in Brussels.

entry.title: Greece news: Alexis Tsipras admits he got a 'bad deal' from Brussels ahead of parliamentary vote â€“ and rules out resigning
entry.summary: "I am fully assuming my responsibilities, for mistakes and for oversights, and for the responsibility of signing a text that I do not believe in, but that I am obliged to implement," Tsipras said.

entry.title: The Latest: German official says Tsipras criticism unhelpful
entry.summary: Tsipras told state TV that "the policies imposed on us were irrational" but the deal was the best Greece could get.

entry.title: The Latest: German official says Tsipras criticism unhelpful
entry.summary: A German official says criticism by Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of the preliminary bailout deal with creditors isn't helpful.

entry.title: Dissent in Greece over austerity deal grows ahead of vote
entry.summary:
Now Tsipras must keep his own government from collapsing as he tries to push a deal that he calls "irrational" through Parliament.

Hard-liners in Tsipras' own Cabinet and his radical leftist Syriza party are in open revolt.

The Tsipras government holds 162 seats in Greece's 300-member Parliament.

entry.title: Dissent in Greece over austerity deal grows ahead of vote
entry.summary:
So after a marathon eurozone summit, Tsipras agreed to tough new measures that mean economically-battered Greeks will pay more for most goods and services by the end of the week.

But the Tsipras government's political survival could be in danger if large numbers of its own lawmakers resign their seats or openly vote against the bill.

Many in Tsipras' party have indicated they will refuse to vote for the deal because it goes back on election pledges to repeal austerity measures that have been imposed on Greece for years.

entry.title: Greece crisis: PM Alexis Tsipras faces tough sell on bailout deal
entry.summary: Energy Minister Panagiotis Lafazanis, one of the hardliners in Tsipras' radical left Syriza party, denounced the deal and called on the prime minister to cancel it before legislation reaches Parliament.

entry.title: Greece PM Tsipras faces dissent on bailout deal
entry.summary: Tsipras is expected to have the numbers in Parliament to pass the measures, since he will have the support of most opposition parties.

entry.title: Tsipras faces bailout deal dissent
entry.summary:
"This deal introduced many new issues ... we cannot agree with it," he said after meeting Mr Tsipras.

Since his election in January, Mr Tsipras has faced intense pressure to backpedal on many of his promises to Greece's exhausted electorate.

Passage of the new measures appears assured, since Greece's opposition parties have pledged to support Mr Tsipras' deal.

entry.title: Greece's Tsipras says deal allows Greece to stand on own feet, averted "extreme measures"
entry.summary: BRUSSELS (AP) " Greece's Tsipras says deal allows Greece to stand on own feet, averted "extreme measures".

entry.title: Tsipras facing pressure to back deal or consider euro exit
entry.summary: The broad outlines of a deal appeared to consist of a long series commitments from Tsipras to push through much of a drastic austerity program within days, while the 18 other eurozone leaders would commit to start talks on a new bailout program.

entry.title: Greek PM Tsipras says he's ready for compromise, bailout deal possible if all parties want it
Greece's Tsipras digs in against bailout
entry.summary:
Less than 24 hours after he wrote a conciliatory letter to creditors asking for a new bailout that would accept many of their terms, Tsipras abruptly switched back into combative mode in a television address.

Euro zone finance ministers held an hour-long conference call to discuss the previous night's offer from Tsipras, but were adamant that no further discussions would be held until after Sunday's vote.

In his overnight letter to creditors, seen by Reuters, Tsipras agreed to accept most of their demands for taxes and pension cuts and asked for a new 29 billion euro loan to cover all debt service payments in the next two years.

Lagarde declined to be drawn out on whether she viewed Tsipras was a reliable negotiating partner after his latest switch, although she did say the Fund wanted to see evidence of reforms before talks about any new potential debt package.

The Tsipras letter asking for a new bailout deal appeared to move closer to accepting creditor demands.

entry.title: Greek debt crisis: Greeks muse on future path after Alexis Tsipras' abrupt reversal
entry.summary: Those are the questions being asked across Greece in the wake of Mr Tsipras' abrupt decision to give the creditors nearly all of what they have sought throughout the long and contentious negotiations over keeping Greece afloat.

entry.title: Greek PM Tsipras seeks party backing after abrupt concessions
entry.summary:
After walking into a party meeting to applause, Tsipras rallied his Syriza lawmakers to throw their weight behind the new proposals ahead of a snap vote in parliament on the negotiations, urging them to help keep Greece in the euro.

Tsipras has called a snap vote in parliament asking for its backing to negotiate a list of "prior actions" -- measures his government would take to convince creditors of its intent for an aid deal, and to secure the first disbursement.

entry.title: Greek PM Tsipras seeks party backing after abrupt concessions
entry.summary: It is unclear whether all the creditors would back the latest reforms package, which was strikingly similar to the terms Greece had rejected in a referendum that Tsipras had called in June.

entry.title: Greek PM Tsipras pushing last-ditch austerity package
entry.summary: But in an unusual procedure, Tsipras is first seeking authorization from parliament to negotiate with the creditors based on the proposal in a vote Friday.

entry.title: Greece's Tsipras to sell last-ditch deal to reluctant party
entry.summary:
Tsipras will seek backing for a harsh new austerity package from his party Friday to keep his country in the euro - less than a week after urging Greeks to reject milder cuts in a referendum.

Tsipras could face a tough battle to convince his party hardliners to back his proposal.

entry.title: Greece's Tsipras to sell last-ditch deal to reluctant party
entry.summary: Tsipras was convening his party's lawmakers for discussions Friday morning before the parliamentary debate.

entry.title: Greek debt crisis: France to the rescue as Tsipras accepts austerity for relief
entry.summary:
"We are confronted with crucial decisions," a government official quoted Mr Tsipras telling his party colleagues.

But Mr Tsipras seemed to have gained ground on debt relief, his one bedrock demand.

Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras (seated) is applauded by his colleagues in the ruling Syriza party inside the Greek parliament.

entry.title: Greece's Tsipras to sell last-ditch deal to reluctant party
Draghi said to doubt Greek solution as Tsipras reforms awaited
entry.summary: Such measures may face resistance from the hard-left wing of Tsipras' Syriza party and from his junior coalition partner, the Independent Greeks, after the government won a resounding 'No' to more austerity in a referendum on July 5.

entry.title: After vote win, Greece's Tsipras looks to rebuild talks
entry.summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras heads Tuesday to Brussels, where he will try to use a bailout referendum victory to obtain a rescue deal with European leaders.

entry.title: Greek PM Tsipras races to restart talks after vote win
entry.summary:
Tsipras faces intense pressure from creditors abroad and banks at home who all demand what Greece lacks: money.

In a sign of compromise, Tsipras appointed a new finance minister to lead talks with creditors and replace Yanis Varoufakis, who clashed with his European counterparts.

entry.title: After vote win, Greece's Tsipras looks to rebuild talks
entry.summary: Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, left, leaves a polling station after voting in Athens, Sunday, July 5, 2015.

entry.title: After vote win, Greece's Tsipras looks to rebuild talks
entry.summary:
Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras won big in Sunday's referendum, in which 60 percent of Greeks rejected the economic measures creditors had proposed in exchange for loans the country needs to remain afloat.

That meeting is meant to seek the basis for a deal that European leaders, including Tsipras, might discuss at an emergency summit later in the day.

Ahead of the summit, Tsipras spoke by phone with German Chancellor Angela Merkel.

Tsipras has agreed to imposing more harsh austerity measures, following a six-year recession, but wants eurozone lenders to grant the country better terms for bailout debt repayments.

entry.title: After vote win, Greece's Tsipras looks to rebuild talks
Tsipras dismisses Europe's warnings to Greece on vote
entry.summary: Already, Tsipras' coalition is under strain as a succession of deputies from the right-wing Independent Greeks, his junior partners, have backed the 'Yes' vote.

entry.title: Tsipras dismisses Europe's warnings to Greece on vote
entry.summary: Tsipras may not survive long if voters ignore his call to vote 'No'.

entry.title: Tsipras dismisses Europe's warnings to Greece on vote
entry.summary: Tsipras is betting Europe will compromise rather than let Greece slip out of the eurozone, even though the continent's leaders say a "No" vote would signal its exit.

entry.title: Greek PM Tsipras says IMF report fully justifies Greece's position on debt relief
Greece's Tsipras digs in against bailout
entry.summary:
"We will come back to your request for financial stability support from the ESM (European Stability Mechanism) only after, and on the basis of the outcome of, the referendum," the head of the currency zone ministers' Eurogroup, Jeroen Dijsselbloem, wrote in a letter to Tsipras.

Tsipras has suggested he would step aside if Greeks vote "Yes" in Sunday's referendum.

entry.title: Tsipras defiant as banks shut, markets rocked
entry.summary: Greece's parliament voted early Sunday in favor of Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' motion to hold a July 5 referendum on creditor proposals for reforms in exchange for loans.

entry.title: Tsipras defiant as banks shut, markets rocked
entry.summary: Tsipras called the referendum over the weekend, arguing that demands for tougher austerity measures could not be accepted after six years of recession.

entry.title: Tsipras defiant as banks shut, markets rocked
entry.summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras was defiant, urging voters to reject creditors' demands, insisting a "No" vote in next Sunday's referendum would strengthen Athens' negotiating hand.

entry.title: Tsipras defiant as banks shut, markets rocked
entry.summary:
Tsipras says the Bank of Greece has recommended that banks remain closed and restrictions be imposed on transactions, after the European Central Bank didn't increase the amount of emergency liquidity the lenders can access from the central bank.

In this photo taken from ERT State Television, Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras delivers a televised address to the nation from his office at Maximos Mansion in Athens, Sunday, June 28, 2015.

entry.title: Tsipras defiant as banks shut, markets rocked
entry.summary: Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, right, speaks with journalist Panos Haritos before a TV interview at the State Television (ERT) in Athens, Monday, June 29, 2015.

entry.title: Greece to introduce capital controls, keep banks shut as crisis deepens
entry.summary: The creditors want Greece to cut pensions and raise taxes in ways that Tsipras has long argued would deepen one of the worst economic crises of modern times in a country where a quarter of the workforce is already unemployed.

entry.title: Greek minister calls on nation to reject bailout deal
entry.summary: Lafazanis spoke early Saturday, after an emergency cabinet meeting during which Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras announced his intention to call the referendum.

entry.title: Greek PM Tsipras presents new financial proposal to EU
entry.summary:
A government source close to the talks says Tsipras "presented to the three leaders Greece's proposal for a mutually beneficial agreement, which will provide a permanent solution and not just postpone tackling the problem."

Tsipras has been meeting with his senior ministers all day and will leave for Brussels later Sunday.

entry.title: Greece's Tsipras presented proposal to EU leaders: PM's office
